Pennsylvania American Water

EPA Risk Management Program

Executive Summary

This Risk Mamagement Program has been developed and implrmented in conjunction with the United States Envirionmental Protection Agency (EPA) and under the authority of Section 113 of the Clean Air Act Ammendments (CAAA) of 1990.

This program and the corresponding Process Safety Management Program (PSM) which has been in effect at Pennsylvania American Water (PAW) since May 1, 1994, are intended to prevent and minimize the impacts of the accidental release of chlorine. Chlorine is listed as an extremely hazardous substance by both EPA and OSHA. All PAW facilities at or above the EPA threshold amount of 2500 pounds of chlorine is subject to the EPPA CAAA regulations and will comply.

By this narrative we incorporate by reference all aspects of the PAW Process Safety Management Program (PSM) including but not limited to Hazard Assessments, Prevention Programs, Emergency Response Programs and the American Water system Risk Management Manual.

Each Treatment Plant covered by the EPA RMP Guidelines is also covered by the OSHA PSM program. A PSM manual and an American Water system Risk Management Manual is available at each plant location for review.

All Emergency Response procedures are included at the treatment plant.  Procedures involving evacuation of the plant are included. Procedures involving the emergency response to a chemical release are located at the plant and all plant personnel are trained in the appropriate action to be taken.  Procedures involving communication and evacuation of the public are deferred to the Local Emerency Planning Committee (LEPC) of the local agency responsivble for emergency coordination.
